content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would opt for strategy B{B} in this game. Here's my reasoning:

1. In any two-player, zero-sum game like this one, there exists an optimal strategy that maximizes the expected payoff for each player.

2. Let's assume you pick R, and your opponent picks R as well (this gives us both 45$). If instead, they picked B when you picked R, they would get 40$, while you would get nothing. So if we only focus on the 'R-vs-R' and 'R-vs-B' scenarios, it seems better to pick R only if you can guarantee that your opponent will also pick R (since getting 45$ is better than getting 0$).

3. However, since your opponent is anonymous, there's no way for us to force them into picking R every time. In fact, they might be playing the same logic we are and choose B whenever you pick R, getting 40$ each time while you get nothing. This means that if we always pick R when given a choice between R and B, we end up with a negative payoff for most of the game (75 rounds).

4. On the other hand, if we choose strategy B{B}, we will get 20$ in every round where our opponent also picks B. Since there are 75 rounds, we'll get 1500$ in total. If our opponent tries to exploit us by picking R when they think we'll pick B, they will only earn 45$ for that round, which is less than what they would have earned if they had picked B as well (75 rounds * 20$ = 1500$).

5. In summary, strategy B{B} maximizes our expected payoff in this game because it guarantees us a steady income of 20$ per round while also making it less profitable for our opponent to deviate from their optimal strategy (which is picking B when we pick B).
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

Given that I picked B in the previous round, and my opponent picked R, I will stick with strategy B for the next round as well (B{B}).

In this particular scenario, my opponent chose R when I picked B, which means they got nothing while I received 40$. If we continue to pick B whenever our opponent picks R, we can maximize our earnings in the long run.

However, if my opponent were to change their strategy and pick B whenever I pick R (a dominant strategy), then I would switch my strategy to picking R whenever they pick B, which guarantees me a 45$ payoff each time they pick B (since they will always pick R when I do). In this case, the optimal strategy for me would be to play R{R}.

But since we don't have information about our opponent's future behavior, it is best to stick with the initial strategy of B{B} for now.

However, if our opponent were to change their strategy and pick R whenever I pick B (a dominant strategy), then I would switch my strategy to picking R whenever they pick B (R{R}). In this case, the optimal strategy for me would be to play R{R} starting from now. But since we don't have information about our opponent's future behavior, it is best to stick with the initial strategy of B{B} for now.
